name: Manali
fun_fact: Fun fact: Manali means 'the abode of Manu' - according to Hindu mythology, the sage Manu stepped off his ark here to recreate human life after a great flood! Known as the 'Valley of the Gods,' this Himalayan hill station at 6,726 feet is home to the unique Hadimba Temple, built in 1553 to honor a demoness who became a deity through years of devotion. The temple's pagoda-style roof and cedar forest setting are magical!

hero_dishes.name: Siddu
hero_dishes.description: Steamed bread made from wheat flour with a savory filling of peas, green chilies, and spices. Served piping hot with ghee (clarified butter) dripping over it, or with mutton curry. Soft, pillowy, and absolutely comforting in the cold mountain air.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A traditional Himachali dish that has sustained mountain people for centuries. The steaming method (rather than baking) made it practical in areas where ovens were rare. Each family has their own filling variations passed down generations.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Local Himachali restaurants throughout Manali. Best experienced at guesthouses in Old Manali and Vashisht where home-style cooking is offered. Ask for it at traditional eateries on Mall Road.

hero_dishes.name: Dham
hero_dishes.description: An elaborate traditional Himachali feast prepared during festivals and special occasions. Fully vegetarian with rice, rajma (kidney beans), lentils, and curd, all generously dressed in ghee and mild spices. Served on a leaf platter (traditionally).
hero_dishes.origin_story: Dham is more than food - it's a ceremonial meal prepared by specialized cooks called 'botis' who learned the craft from their ancestors. Each region of Himachal has variations, but the essence remains: community, celebration, and comfort.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Dham is primarily served at festivals, weddings, and temple celebrations. Some traditional restaurants may offer it on special request or during festival seasons. Check with local guesthouses for authentic experiences.

hero_dishes.name: Trout Fish
hero_dishes.description: Freshly caught trout from the Beas River, grilled or fried to perfection. The fish is incredibly fresh (sometimes caught the same day), with delicate, flaky meat. Usually served with local herbs and lemon.
hero_dishes.origin_story: The Beas River running through Manali is famous for its trout. What started as a British colonial introduction became a local specialty. Fishing and eating fresh trout became part of Manali's mountain culture.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Johnson's Cafe (Circuit House Road, Old Manali) is legendary - they have ten unique renditions including baked trout with almond sauce and trout curry with steamed spinach and traditional Himachali red rice. Also at local restaurants along the river.

hero_dishes.name: Thukpa
hero_dishes.description: A hearty Tibetan noodle soup with vegetables and/or meat in a flavorful broth. Perfect for cold Himalayan evenings, steaming hot and deeply comforting with a hint of spice.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Tibetan refugees and the proximity to Tibet brought this dish to Himachal Pradesh. Thukpa represents the beautiful cultural blend in mountain regions where Tibetan, Himachali, and North Indian influences meet.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Chopsticks Restaurant (Manu Temple Road, Old Manali) is famous for Thukpa and Yak Cheese Momos. Available at most Tibetan restaurants and caf√©s in Old Manali area.

hero_dishes.name: Chana Madra
hero_dishes.description: A heartwarming chickpea curry with vegetables, cooked with yogurt and aromatic Indian spices - cumin, cardamom, cloves, cinnamon, coriander powder, and turmeric. Rich, creamy, and fragrant. Best with rice or roti.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Madra is quintessentially Himachali, showcasing the region's love for yogurt-based curries that are rich without being heavy. The spice blend reflects the trade routes through the mountains bringing varied spices to Himachal.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional Himachali restaurants throughout Manali. Renaissance, Basil Leaf Restaurant, and local eateries on Mall Road serve authentic versions.

signature_drinks.name: Kahwa (Kashmiri Tea)
signature_drinks.description: A traditional green tea infused with saffron, cinnamon, cardamom, and almonds. Sweet, aromatic, and warming - perfect for high-altitude cold.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Sipped throughout the day, especially in the morning and evening. Locals add a touch of honey. It's both a social drink and a medicinal one - believed to aid digestion and warm the body in mountain cold.

signature_drinks.name: Masala Chai
signature_drinks.description: Strong black tea boiled with milk, sugar, and spices (ginger, cardamom, cloves). The mountain version is particularly robust to fight the cold.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Constantly! Chai stalls are everywhere in Manali. Locals drink it with breakfast, mid-morning, afternoon, evening - basically whenever they need warming up. Often enjoyed with pakoras (fritters) or biscuits.

signature_drinks.name: Local Apple Juice
signature_drinks.description: Fresh apple juice from Himachal's famous apple orchards. The state is India's apple capital, and Manali area produces excellent varieties.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Fresh and unfiltered from roadside vendors and caf√©s. The sweetness and freshness beat any packaged version. During apple season (September-October), it's everywhere.

food_culture_notes: Manali sits at 6,726 feet in the Kullu Valley, surrounded by Himalayan peaks - the cold weather shapes food culture toward warming, ghee-rich dishes
The area blends Himachali, Tibetan, and North Indian cuisines due to its position as a trading route and tourist destination
Old Manali has evolved a traveler caf√© culture - Italian pizzas, Israeli food, continental breakfast - sitting alongside traditional Himachali food
Johnson's Cafe pioneered the fusion of local ingredients (Himachali red rice, trout) with international preparation styles
Mall Road is packed with North Indian eateries serving butter chicken and shahi paneer (rich tourist-friendly options)
Vashisht and Old Manali lanes offer more authentic, budget-friendly eateries with local guesthouses serving home-cooked meals
Himachali cuisine emphasizes minimal use of onion and garlic in some traditional dishes, relying on yogurt and asafoetida instead
The influence of Tibetan refugees is strong - momos, thukpa, and Tibetan bread are mainstream
Locals still celebrate with traditional Dham feasts at temples and special occasions, maintaining ancient culinary traditions
Manali's apple orchards and the broader Himachal apple industry make apple-based products (juice, preserves, pies) common
